Name: Containers , URL: /wiki/Solaris_Zones
Typical use: Server consolidation with workload isolation, single workload containment, hosting, dev/test/prod

Name: Hyper-V , URL: /wiki/Hyper-V
SMP , URL: /wiki/Symmetric_multiprocessi: Yes, up to 4 VCPUs per VM
Typical use: Server consolidation, service continuity, dev/test, desktop virtualization, cloud computing

Name: KVM , URL: /wiki/Kernel-based_Virtual_Machine
Typical use: Virtualized server isolation, server/desktop consolidation, software development, cloud computing, other purposes

Name: Linux-VServer , URL: /wiki/Linux-VServer
Typical use: Virtualized server isolation and security, server consolidation, cloud computing

Name: Oracle VM Server for x86 , URL: /wiki/Oracle_VM_Server_for_x86
Typical use: Server consolidation and security, enterprise and business deployment

Name: Oracle VM Server for SPARC , URL: /wiki/Oracle_VM_Server_for_SPARC
Typical use: Server consolidation and security, enterprise and business deployment

Name: OVPsim , URL: /wiki/OVPsim
Method of operation: Full system simulation with optional component virtualization
Typical use: Software development (early, embedded), advanced debug for single and multicore software, compiler and other tool development, computer architecture research, hobbyist
Speed relative to host OS: Depends on target architecture (full and slow hardware emulation for guests incompatible with host)[citation needed]
Commercial support available: Yes, with commercial license from Imperas[17]

Name: ScaleMP vSMP Foundation
SMP , URL: /wiki/Symmetric_multiprocessi: Yes, up to 8,192 CPUs and 64 TB per VM[citation needed]

Name: Simics , URL: /wiki/Simics
Method of operation: Full system simulation of processors, MMUs, devices, disks, memories, networks, etc.
Typical use: Software development, advanced debug for single and multicore software, compiler and other tool development, computer architecture research, bug transportation, automated testing, system architecture, long-term support of safety-critical systems, early hardware availability, virtual prototyping
Speed relative to host OS: Depends on host machine and target architecture. Runs at near-native speeds for x86-on-x86 using VT-x, cross-simulation of other architectures can be faster or slower than real-time depending on how fast the target is and how big the target is (number of processors, number of target machines, and how much the simulation can be parallelized)

Name: User Mode Linux , URL: /wiki/User_Mode_Linux
Typical use: Developer (as a separate machine for a server or with X11 networking)
Speed relative to host OS: Non-significantly slower than native [9] (all calls to kernel are proxied)[citation needed]

Name: OKL4 Microvisor , URL: /wiki/Open_Kernel_Labs
Runs arbitrary OS: Yes, (either with para-virtualization or HW virtualization)
Typical use: Mobile, embedded, security, safety critical, networking, legacy OS, etc.

Name: VirtualBox , URL: /wiki/VirtualBox
Typical use: Business workstation, server consolidation, service continuity, developer, hobbyist

Name: Virtual PC , URL: /wiki/Microsoft_Virtual_PC
Speed relative to host OS: Up to near native[citation needed] with virtual machine additions

Name: Windows Virtual PC , URL: /wiki/Windows_Virtual_PC
Typical use: Developer, Business workstation, support for Compatibility with Windows XP applications
Speed relative to host OS: Up to near native[citation needed] with virtual machine additions

Name: Virtual Server , URL: /wiki/Microsoft_Virtual_Server
Speed relative to host OS: Up to near native with virtual machine additions but slower than with hypervisor due to proxied calls[citation needed]

Name:
CoWare , URL: /wiki/CoWare
Virtual Platform , URL: /wiki/Virtual_Platform
drivers , URL: /wiki/Device_driver: Yes ( Same compiled Software image as for the real device)
Method of operation: Full-system virtualization (Processor Core ISA + Hardware + External connections)
Speed relative to host OS: Depending on the system characteristics and the software itself, ranges from faster than real time to slow[citation needed].

Name: Virtuozzo , URL: /wiki/Virtuozzo
Typical use: Server consolidation, service continuity, disaster recovery, service providers

Name: VMware ESX Server , URL: /wiki/VMware_ESX_Server
Typical use: Server consolidation, service continuity, dev/test, cloud computing

Name: VMware Workstation , URL: /wiki/VMware_Workstation
Method of operation:
Paravirtualization , URL: /wiki/Paravirtualization
VMI , URL: /w/index.php?title=Virtual_Machine_Interface&action=edit&redlink=1
virtualization , URL: /wiki/X86_virtualization

Name: VMware Player , URL: /wiki/VMware_Player
Typical use: Technical professional, advanced dev/test, trainer, end user on prebuilt machines

Name: Xen , URL: /wiki/Xen
SMP , URL: /wiki/Symmetric_multiprocessi: Yes, v4.0.0: up to 128 VCPUs per VM
Typical use: Virtualized server isolation, server/desktop consolidation, software development, cloud computing, other purposes. Xen powers most public cloud services and many hosting services, such as Amazon Web Services, Rackspace Hosting and Linode.

Name: XCP-ng
Typical use: Virtualized server isolation, server/desktop consolidation, software development, cloud computing, desktop virtualization, public cloud services, hostings services and other purposes.

Name: XenServer , URL: /wiki/XenServer
Typical use: Virtualized server isolation, server/desktop consolidation, software development, cloud computing, other purposes. Xen powers most public cloud services and many hosting services, such as Amazon Web Services, Rackspace Hosting and Linode.

Name: z/VM , URL: /wiki/Z/VM
SMP , URL: /wiki/Symmetric_multiprocessi: Yes, both real and virtual (guest perceives more CPUs than installed), incl. dynamic CPU provisioning and reassignment
Method of operation: Virtualization (among first systems to provide hardware assists)

Name: LPARs , URL: /wiki/LPAR
SMP , URL: /wiki/Symmetric_multiprocessi: Yes, both real and virtual (guest perceives more CPUs than installed), incl. dynamic CPU provisioning and reassignment; up to 64 real cores
